title: Proteotoxic stress response drives T cell exhaustion and immune evasion
summary:
Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09539-1

A proteotoxic stress response specific to exhausted T cells, governed by AKT signaling and accompanied by increased protein translation, represents a mech…
body: Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09539-1 A proteotoxic stress response specific to exhausted T cells, governed by AKT signaling and accompanied by increased protein translation, represents a mechanistic vulnerability and a new therapeutic target to improve cancer immunotherapies.

title: Efferocytic remodelling of pancreatic islet macrophages by limited β-cell death
summary:
Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09560-4

Enrichment for efferocytic macrophages in the islets of Langerhans promotes the accumulation of anergic-like CD4+ T cells and dampens autoimmune diabetes.
body: Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09560-4 Enrichment for efferocytic macrophages in the islets of Langerhans promotes the accumulation of anergic-like CD4+ T cells and dampens autoimmune diabetes.

title: A new paradigm for outer membrane protein biogenesis in the Bacteroidota
summary:
Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09532-8

Structural and biochemical studies of the β-barrel-assembly machinery from Flavobacterium johnsoniae reveal a subunit composition and assembly that are di…
body: Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09532-8 Structural and biochemical studies of the β-barrel-assembly machinery from Flavobacterium johnsoniae reveal a subunit composition and assembly that are distinct from those of the canonical Escherichia coli complex.

title: Heat-rechargeable computation in DNA logic circuits and neural networks
summary:
Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09570-2

Heat recharges enzyme-free DNA circuits, enabling complex logic operations and neural networks to perform multiple computations, offering a universal ener…
body: Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09570-2 Heat recharges enzyme-free DNA circuits, enabling complex logic operations and neural networks to perform multiple computations, offering a universal energy source for molecular machines and advancing autonomous behaviours in artificial chemical systems.

title: Polygenic and developmental profiles of autism differ by age at diagnosis
summary:
Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09542-6

A study of several longitudinal birth cohorts and cross-sectional cohorts finds only moderate overlap in genetic variants between autism that is diagnosed…
body: Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09542-6 A study of several longitudinal birth cohorts and cross-sectional cohorts finds only moderate overlap in genetic variants between autism that is diagnosed earlier and that diagnosed later, so they may represent aetiologically different conditions.

title: Doughnut of social and planetary boundaries monitors a world out of balance
summary:
Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09385-1

A revised ‘Doughnut’ providing a visual assessment of trends in social deprivation and planetary degradation over the past two decades shows more than dou…
body: Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09385-1 A revised ‘Doughnut’ providing a visual assessment of trends in social deprivation and planetary degradation over the past two decades shows more than doubling of global GDP accompanied by accelerating ecological overshoot but only a modest reduction in human deprivation.

summary:
Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09484-z

Experimental evidence demonstrates long-distance remote epitaxial interactions of thin films even through thick amorphous carbon buffer layers and shows t…
body: Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09484-z Experimental evidence demonstrates long-distance remote epitaxial interactions of thin films even through thick amorphous carbon buffer layers and shows that these can be induced through dislocations in the substrate.

title: Autoimmune response to C9orf72 protein in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
summary:

An analysis of T cell responses in people with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis shows that the C9orf72 antigen is a key target of autoimmune responses in the…
body: Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09588-6 An analysis of T cell responses in people with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis shows that the C9orf72 antigen is a key target of autoimmune responses in the disease, and identifies C9orf72 epitopes that are recognized.

body: Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09524-8 An ensemble of spins from nitrogen–vacancy centres in diamonds is prepared in a spin-squeezed state.

title: Evolution of drug-resistant ovarian-cancer clones tracked in patients
summary:
Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03163-9

After an initial treatment response, most ovarian cancers recur because of drug-resistant cell populations. Blood-based tracking, used to monitor clonal e…
body: Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03163-9 After an initial treatment response, most ovarian cancers recur because of drug-resistant cell populations. Blood-based tracking, used to monitor clonal evolution in 18 patients, shows that drug-resistant clones are already present at diagnosis, expand during therapy and contain distinctive genomic alterations that have potential therapeutic relevance.

title: Elaborate machinery for inserting proteins into the outer membrane of bacteria
summary:
Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03154-w

Bacteria insert proteins into their outer membrane using a highly conserved apparatus known as the β-barrel assembly machinery (BAM). A large group of bac…
body: Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03154-w Bacteria insert proteins into their outer membrane using a highly conserved apparatus known as the β-barrel assembly machinery (BAM). A large group of bacteria with particularly complex outer-membrane proteins is now shown to have a BAM apparatus with a highly unusual composition.

body: Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03125-1 Some bacterial-infecting viruses use ‘sponges’ to mop up defence molecules, but bacteria can fight back by responding when a sponge captures decoy molecules.
